instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green/Amber Light no fan
threads.message:
2013 Air board1.4ghz

Green Light/Switches to amber, no fan.

All rails present up to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> which measures at 1.72V 

diode measurement at <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 0.438

Checked around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and it all "looks" fine. No obvious liquid damage to board. 

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> is next on the power rails, but doesn't that come from the I/O board? it is 0V (diode 0.421).

Known working I/O board, measures fine on another board.

Any help or ideas?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green/Amber Light no fan
threads.message:
Before we get to troubleshooting <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing, let's go over <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>: it's your job to tell me why that rail's creation has nothing to do with the I/O board.

Onto <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, which is main issue.

1) Is <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> receiving 8.4v on pin 23? This is required to power the chip. If 8.4v is NOT on pin 23, blown internal board via/trace. Fix with wire.
2) Is <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> receiving 3.3v on pin 12? This <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> signal tells the chip after it has turned on, that it should enable the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> rail. If not, then perhaps <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is bad and pulling it down, OR SMC is not creating it. Bad SMC perhaps.

If answers are both yes, then it's time to figure out why <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is low. You have ruled out a short to ground, which means bad chip. Replace <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green/Amber Light no fan
threads.message:
PIN 23 - 8.57V
PIN 12 - 3.4V

So I am going with bad <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.

It does look as though <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> creates <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> as well... does it go to the i/o board for USB power?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green/Amber Light no fan
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green/Amber Light no fan
threads.message: Ha. Thanks. Any tips on replacing the <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>? Pretty much just like an ISL/<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Green/Amber Light no fan
threads.message:
You'll be proud Louis... I had to use my brain! Haha. 

Replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> twice. 5v was not showing up either time (1.7v.) The chip was getting hot... I finally took diode measurements of all the pins on the board where the <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> goes. I figured out the 3.3 lines were shorted to ground by <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>. I replaced that and the short went away. Replaced the <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> one more time and fan spins and passes ASD and boots, etc... 

Thanks again for all your help and your "teaching" moment. The forum is an awesome resource and I hope you and Duke and all the other contributors stick around for quite a while!

On a side note, if you read this post. Do you still offer the week of training/teaching in your NYC office? I'd still be interested in that...

Thanks!

Will Bailey
